questions.question: Unless you ……………………… drinking, you will develop serious health problems.
questions.description: In the first conditional we use a simple present tense in the if-clause and will + infinitive in the main clause.

questions.question: ………………………. I tried harder, I could have won.
questions.description: Had I tried harder means the same as ‘if I had tried harder’. This sentence is in the third conditional.

questions.question: Provided that you ……………………… now, you will be able to reach there before sunset.
questions.description: In the first conditional we use a simple present tense in the if-clause and will + infinitive in the main clause.

questions.question: If I ………………………….. you, I should get that car serviced.
questions.description: The structure if I were you is used to give advice.

questions.question: If I were you, I …………………………… worry.
questions.description: In the second conditional we use a simple past tense in the if-clause and would + infinitive in the main clause.

questions.question: Had I realized what you intended, I ………………………….. to come with you.
questions.description: In the third conditional, we use a past perfect tense in the if-clause and would have + past participle in the main clause.

questions.question: I will get up earlier if there ……………………… a good reason to.
questions.description: In the first conditional we use a simple present tense in the if-clause and will + infinitive in the main clause.

questions.question: It would be nice if you …………………………… me with the housework.
questions.description: In the second conditional we use a simple past tense in the if-clause and would + infinitive in the main clause.

questions.question: ………………………….. you free, we could go out for a meal.
questions.description: 'Were you free' means the same as ‘if you were free’.

questions.question: If you ………………………… early, give me a ring.
questions.description: 'If you should finish' means more or less the same as 'if you finish'.

questions.question: If you ………………………….. meet James, perhaps you could tell him the news.
questions.description: If you should meet James means the same as If you happen to meet James.

questions.question: How would we cope if I …………………………. to lose my job?
questions.description: In the second conditional we use a simple past tense in the if-clause and would + infinitive in the main clause.
